questions.text: In a healthy adult male, the average daily iron absorption from dietary sources is approximately:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 mg

 

Option B:

 

Adult men typically require about ~1 mg of iron to be absorbed from the diet daily to maintain iron balance and replace losses.

 

Educational objective:

 

Iron Absorption of ~1mg/d is required from the diet in men, and 1.4mg/d in women to maintain homeostasis.

questions.text: Which of the following substances can IMPAIR the absorption of iron supplements?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antacids

 

Option D:

 

Antacids neutralize stomach acid, which is necessary for the conversion of ferric iron (Fe3+) to ferrous iron (Fe2+), the form that is more readily absorbed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option (A, B, C): Vitamin C (in ascorbic acid and orange juice) and meat can all improve iron absorption.

 

Educational objective:

 

Patients taking iron supplements should avoid taking antacids concurrently, as this can reduce absorption.

choices.text: Within 24-48 hours of starting therapy
3-4 days after starting therapy
7-10 days after starting therapy
14-21 days after starting therapy

questions.text: A patient with iron deficiency anemia is started on oral iron supplementation. When would you expect to see the PEAK reticulocyte response, indicating that the bone marrow is actively producing new red blood cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 7-10 days after starting therapy

 

Option C:

 

The peak reticulocyte response typically occurs within 1-1.5 weeks (7-10 days) after starting iron therapy. This indicates a robust response from the bone marrow to correct the anemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Within 24-48 hours of starting therapy: This is too soon to expect a peak response. It takes several days for the bone marrow to ramp up red blood cell production.

 

Option B. 3-4 days after starting therapy: While the reticulocyte count may start to rise within 3-4 days, the peak response is typically later.

 

Option D. 14-21 days after starting therapy: This is too late for the peak response. If there's no significant increase by this time, it could suggest a lack of response to therapy or an alternative diagnosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

The reticulocyte count is a valuable tool for monitoring the response to iron therapy in iron deficiency anemia. An increase in reticulocytes within 4-7 days and a peak response at 7-10 days are expected findings, indicating that the treatment is effective.

questions.text: Which of the following alpha-globin gene arrangements is MOST likely to be associated with Hemoglobin H (HbH) disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) --/-α

 

Option D:

 

HbH disease is caused by the deletion or inactivation of three out of four alpha-globin genes. The genotype "--/-α" represents this condition, where one chromosome has both alpha-globin genes deleted, and the other chromosome has one alpha-globin gene deleted.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. αα/αα: α-thal. With Myelodysplasia - Mutations in ATRX; striking male predominance. Hematologic findings of HbH disease.

 

Option B. -α/αα: Represents the silent carrier state of alpha-thalassemia, with only one alpha-globin gene deleted. It typically doesn't cause significant clinical symptoms.

 

Option C. --/αα: Represents alpha-thalassemia trait, where two alpha-globin genes are deleted. This condition can lead to mild anemia but is not associated with HbH disease.

 

Educational objective:

 

The specific arrangement and number of alpha-globin gene deletions determine the severity of alpha-thalassemia. HbH disease, a moderate form of the condition, is caused by the deletion or inactivation of three out of four alpha-globin genes, represented by the genotype --/-α (other gene arrangement: αTα/- -, αTα/αTα)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of mild anemia on routine blood work presents for a follow-up appointment. She reports good energy levels and denies any recent illnesses or blood loss. Her physical examination is unremarkable. A peripheral blood smear is shown in the image. Which of the following hematological conditions is MOST likely represented in this blood smear?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Beta-thalassemia intermedia

 

Option D:

 

The image shows target cells and marked variation in cell size (anisocytosis) and shape (poikilocytosis), along with hypochromia (pale red blood cells) and microcytosis (small red blood cells). These are hallmark features of beta-thalassemia intermedia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: While also microcytic and hypochromic, it usually does not exhibit target cells or the degree of poikilocytosis seen here.

 

Option B. Vitamin B12 deficiency: Causes macrocytic (large red blood cell) anemia, not microcytic.

 

Option C. Sickle cell anemia: Characterized by sickle-shaped red blood cells, which are not present in this image.

 

Educational objective:

 

The presence of target cells, anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, hypochromia and microcytosis in a blood smear strongly suggests beta-thalassemia intermedia.

choices.text: Positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT) with anti-IgG specificity
Positive DAT with anti-C3d specificity
Positive DAT with anti-IgM specificity

questions.text: A patient presents with anemia and acrocyanosis that worsens in cold weather. Which of the following laboratory findings is most consistent with cold agglutinin syndrome (CAS)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Positive DAT with anti-IgM specificity

 

Option C:

 

CAS is caused by IgM autoantibodies that bind to red blood cells at low temperatures, leading to agglutination and hemolysis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT) with anti-IgG specificity and Option B. Positive DAT with anti-C3d specificity are more commonly associated with WAIHA.

 

Option D. Negative DAT: A negative DAT would not be expected in a patient with autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

 

Educational objective:

 

A positive DAT with anti-IgM specificity is a key laboratory finding in the diagnosis of CAS.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of lymphoma presents with fatigue, jaundice, and splenomegaly. Peripheral blood smear shows spherocytes. Which of the following is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia (WAIHA)

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation of fatigue, jaundice, and splenomegaly, along with spherocytes on peripheral smear, is most consistent with WAIHA. The history of lymphoma increases the likelihood of WAIHA, as some types of lymphoma can trigger autoimmune responses.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cold agglutinin disease (CAD): Primarily presents with acrocyanosis and anemia, and blood smear often reveals agglutination.

 

Option B. Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH): Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) is rare and typically presents with biphasic hemolysis and hemoglobinuria after cold exposure.

 

Option D. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA): Presents with schistocytes on peripheral smear and is associated with underlying conditions like thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) or hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

 

Educational objective:

 

WAIHA is the most common type of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and can be associated with underlying lymphoproliferative disorders like lymphoma

choices.text: Decreasing red blood cell sickling
Blocking adhesive interactions between sickle cells and endothelial cells

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with sickle cell disease (SCD) and a history of frequent vaso-occlusive crises is being considered for treatment with crizanlizumab, a monoclonal antibody that targets P-selectin. What is the PRIMARY mechanism of action of crizanlizumab in preventing vaso-occlusive crises in SCD?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blocking adhesive interactions between sickle cells and endothelial cells

 

Option D:

 

Crizanlizumab, a P-selectin inhibitor, works by preventing the adhesion of sickle cells to the endothelium, thereby reducing the risk of vaso-occlusion and subsequent painful crises.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increasing fetal hemoglobin (HbF) levels: Hydroxyurea, not crizanlizumab, is the primary medication used to increase HbF levels in sickle cell disease.

 

Option B. Decreasing red blood cell sickling: While reducing adhesion can indirectly help prevent sickling, crizanlizumab's primary mechanism is not directly targeting the sickling process itself.

 

Option C. Inhibiting platelet aggregation: While platelets play a role in vaso-occlusion, crizanlizumab's primary target is P-selectin on endothelial cells, not platelets.

 

Educational objective:

 

P-selectin blockade is a novel therapeutic approach in SCD that targets the adhesive interactions involved in vaso-occlusion.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of worsening fatigue. His mother reports that he seems to have trouble keeping up with his older brothers when playing outside. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. A hemoglobin electrophoresis is performed. This patient's results are shown in comparison to those of a patient with known sickle cell anemia and a child with normal hemoglobin. Based on this electrophoresis, which of the following types of hemoglobin are dominant in this patient's blood?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HbS and HbC

 

Option D:

 

HbA (α2β2), which is the predominant form of hemoglobin by the age of 6 months, migrates farther than HbS, which is the predominant hemoglobin of patients with sickle cell disease. This is because HbS contains a neutral valine residue at position 6 within the beta subunit in place of the normal, negatively charged glutamic acid residue. HbS, in turn, migrates farther than HbC because HbC contains a positively charged lysine residue in the same position. The thin band between HbS and HbA in the sickle cell patient's sample is HbF (α2γ2), which is slightly less negatively charged than HbA but more negatively charged than HbS. HbF is normally present in negligible quantities by early childhood but patients with sickle cell disease often have increased levels of HbF. This patient's hemoglobin electrophoresis shows one band at the position of the HbS band and the other at a position closer to the cathode than HbS. Therefore, this patient has HbSC disease. HbSC patients have milder symptoms than those with homozygous sickle cell anemia (HbSS).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HbC only: Individuals homozygous for HbC have hemoglobin C disease, which typically manifests with mild anemia. The electrophoresis pattern of a patient with HbC disease would show a single thicker band that migrates even less than HbS.

 

Option B. HbA and HbC: Individuals with the hemoglobin C trait would have both HbA and HbC in their blood. Hemoglobin electrophoresis of this patient shows HbC but not HbA. Moreover, hemoglobin C trait is usually an asymptomatic carrier state, unlike this patient with fatigue.

 

Option C. HbA and HbS: Individuals heterozygous for the sickle cell trait would have both HbA and HbS in their blood. Hemoglobin electrophoresis of this patient shows HbS but not HbA. Moreover, individuals heterozygous for the sickle cell trait are usually asymptomatic, unlike this patient with fatigue.

questions.text: A 28-year-old African American woman presents with mild anemia and complains of intermittent abdominal pain. On peripheral blood smear, target cells and rhomboid crystals are noted within red blood cells. Given the likely diagnosis, Which of the following amino acid changes is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glutamic acid to lysine

 

Option A:

 

HbC disease is caused by the substitution of glutamic acid with lysine at the sixth position of the beta-globin chain. This change leads to the formation of HbC crystals, which can cause mild to moderate hemolytic anemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Valine to glutamic acid: This substitution is the characteristic change for sickle cell anemia (HbS).

 

Option C. Lysine to glutamic acid: Swapping these two positively charged amino acids would likely have a minimal effect on hemoglobin function.

 

Option D. Glutamic acid to valine: This substitution is also seen in HbS and leads to the polymerization of red blood cells.

 

Educational objective:

 

HbC disease is a milder form of hemoglobinopathy compared to sickle cell disease, but it is important to distinguish it based on the specific amino acid substitution.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with G6PD deficiency presents with jaundice and fatigue. Her laboratory results show hemoglobin of 8 g/dL and elevated indirect bilirubin. Which of the following medications would be MOST likely to trigger this hemolytic episode?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nitrofurantoin

 

Option D:

 

Nitrofurantoin is a known oxidant stressor that can trigger hemolysis in individuals with G6PD deficiency.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  Acetaminophen: Acetaminophen is not a common trigger of G6PD deficiency-related hemolysis.

 

Option B. Penicillin: Penicillin is generally safe in G6PD deficiency.

 

Option C. Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is not a common trigger of G6PD deficiency-related hemolysis.

 

Educational objective:

 

It is crucial to avoid medications that can trigger hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl with hereditary spherocytosis presents with right upper quadrant pain. Ultrasound reveals gallstones. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of gallstone formation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased pigment excretion

 

Option C:

 

Chronic hemolysis in hereditary spherocytosis leads to increased bilirubin production and excretion, which can promote the formation of pigment gallstones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased cholesterol secretion: While cholesterol is a major component of gallstones, increased secretion is not the primary culprit in HS.

 

Option B. Decreased bile acid synthesis: Decreased bile acid synthesis can promote cholesterol gallstones, but it is not a major factor in pigment gallstone formation seen in HS.

 

Option D. Decreased gallbladder motility: Decreased gallbladder motility can contribute to gallstone formation, but it is not the most specific or common finding in HS.

 

Educational objective:

 

Gallstones are a common complication of hereditary spherocytosis due to increased pigment excretion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with fatigue, abdominal pain, and dark urine, especially in the morning. Laboratory tests reveal hemoglobinuria and decreased levels of CD55 and CD59 on red blood cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

 

Option C:

 

The classic triad of symptoms (fatigue, abdominal pain, and dark urine), along with decreased CD55 and CD59 levels on red blood cells, are characteristic of PNH.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia: While it can present with anemia and hemolysis, it typically does not cause hemoglobinuria or have decreased CD55/CD59 levels.

 

Option B. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency: This usually presents with episodic hemolysis triggered by oxidative stress, not specifically at night.

 

Option D. Sickle cell disease: This is a genetic hemoglobinopathy with distinct clinical and laboratory findings.

 

Educational objective:

 

PNH is a rare acquired hemolytic anemia characterized by intravascular hemolysis, often more pronounced at night, and decreased CD55 and CD59 levels on blood cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first-line treatment for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ravulizumab

 

Option B:

 

Eculizumab and ravulizumab are monoclonal antibodies that inhibit complement activation, the underlying mechanism of hemolysis in PNH. They are the first-line treatment options.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Prednisone: While corticosteroids like prednisone may be used in some cases of autoimmune hemolytic anemia, they are not the first-line treatment for PNH. They are less effective than eculizumab or ravulizumab at controlling hemolysis and thrombosis.

 

Option C. Rituximab: Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that targets B cells. While it can be used in some autoimmune disorders, it is not indicated for PNH.

 

Option D. Cyclosporine: Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant used in various conditions, including organ transplantation and some autoimmune disorders. It has no direct effect on the complement system, which is the primary driver of PNH, and thus is not used in its treatment.

 

Educational objective:

 

Eculizumab and ravulizumab have revolutionized the treatment of PNH by significantly reducing hemolysis, thrombosis risk, and improving quality of life.

choices.text: Decreased or absent CD34+ cells

questions.text: Flow cytometry in a patient with suspected aplastic anemia is most likely to reveal:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased or absent CD34+ cells

 

Option B:

 

CD34+ cells are hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells. Their decrease or absence reflects the bone marrow failure in aplastic anemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased CD34+ cells: This would be seen in conditions with increased hematopoietic activity, such as recovery from chemotherapy or certain leukemias. It's not expected in aplastic anemia where the bone marrow is failing.

 

Option C. Increased blasts: Increased blasts (immature blood cells) would suggest acute leukemia or myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), not aplastic anemia.

 

Option D. Monoclonal B-cell population: This finding would be more indicative of a lymphoproliferative disorder, such as chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) or lymphoma, rather than aplastic anemia.

 

Educational objective:

 

Flow cytometry can help confirm the diagnosis of aplastic anemia by demonstrating a lack of CD34+ cells.

choices.text: Microcytic anemia and normal methylmalonic acid (MMA) level
Macrocytic anemia and elevated MMA level
Macrocytic anemia and normal MMA level
Normocytic anemia and elevated homocysteine level

questions.text: A 65-year-old vegan presents with fatigue, pallor, and numbness and tingling in their hands and feet. Which of the following laboratory findings would be MOST consistent with the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Macrocytic anemia and elevated MMA level

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation (fatigue, pallor, neurological symptoms) and vegan diet strongly suggest vitamin B12 deficiency. Macrocytic anemia is a hallmark of B12 deficiency, and elevated MMA levels are specific for this condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Microcytic anemia and normal methylmalonic acid (MMA) level: Microcytic anemia is associated with iron deficiency, not B12 deficiency.

 

Option C. Macrocytic anemia and normal MMA level: While macrocytic anemia is consistent with B12 deficiency, normal MMA levels would not be expected.

 

Option D. Normocytic anemia and elevated homocysteine level: Normocytic anemia is not typical of B12 deficiency, and while homocysteine can be elevated in both B12 and folate deficiencies, it's not specific for B12.

 

Educational objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency should be suspected in vegans presenting with neurological symptoms and macrocytic anemia. Elevated MMA levels are a specific marker for B12 deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is MOST likely to interfere with folate metabolism and potentially lead to folate deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methotrexate

 

Option C:

 

Methotrexate is a dihydrofolate reductase inhibitor, interfering with folate metabolism and leading to functional folate deficiency.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aspirin: While aspirin can cause some minor interference with folate absorption at very high doses, it's not a major contributor to folate deficiency at typical doses.

 

Option B. Metformin: Metformin primarily affects glucose metabolism and doesn't have a direct impact on folate metabolism. However, long-term metformin use has been associated with mild decreases in vitamin B12 levels, which can sometimes be confused with folate deficiency.

 

Option D. Atorvastatin: Atorvastatin is a cholesterol-lowering medication (statin) and does not interfere with folate metabolism.

 

Educational objective:

 

While all medications should be reviewed when a patient presents with folate deficiency, methotrexate stands out as the most likely culprit due to its direct inhibitory effect on dihydrofolate reductase, a key enzyme in folate metabolism.

choices.text: Addition of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to the H antigen
Addition of galactose (Gal) to the H antigen
Removal of fucose from the H antigen
Absence of both GalNAc and Gal on the H antigen

questions.text: Which of the following genetic modifications on chromosome 9 leads to the formation of the B antigen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Addition of galactose (Gal) to the H antigen

 

Option B:

 

The B antigen is formed by the addition of a galactose molecule to the terminal end of the H antigen. This is facilitated by specific glycosyltransferases encoded on chromosome 9.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Addition of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to the H antigen: This modification results in the formation of the A antigen.

 

Option C. Removal of fucose from the H antigen: While removal of fucose is a step in the formation of both A and B antigens, it's not the final step for the B antigen.

 

Option D. Absence of both GalNAc and Gal on the H antigen: This results in the O blood group, where neither A nor B antigens are present.

 

Educational objective:

 

The A and B antigens are formed by modifications of the H antigen.

questions.text: A patient experiences a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR) 5 days after a blood transfusion. Which of the following blood group systems is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kidd

 

Option B:

 

The Kidd blood group system is known for its association with delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions (DHTR), often occurring days after the transfusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Kell: While Kell antibodies can cause severe hemolytic reactions, these are typically acute rather than delayed.

 

Option C. MNS: MNS antibodies can cause delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions, but they are relatively rare compared to Kidd antibodies.

 

Option D. Lewis: Lewis antibodies are naturally occurring and typically of the IgM isotype, which are generally not considered clinically significant in transfusions.

 

Educational objective:

 

Kidd antibodies are typically IgG and can cause severe delayed reactions.

choices.text: DARC (Duffy Antigen Receptor for Chemokines)

questions.text: Which of the following antigen is resistant to P. vivax/knowlesi?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DARC (Duffy Antigen Receptor for Chemokines)

 

Option B:

 

Duffy Antigen Receptor for Chemokines (DARC): The DARC acts as a receptor for both chemokines and Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium knowlesi malaria parasites. Individuals lacking this receptor (Duffy-negative phenotype) are resistant to these types of malaria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. K/k: Kell antigens are a group of antigens found on red blood cells. They are not involved in malaria resistance.

 

Option C. Lewis Ag: Lewis antigens are present in body fluids and can be adsorbed onto red blood cells. They do not play a role in malaria resistance.

 

Option D. A antigen: The A antigen is part of the ABO blood group system and determines blood type. It has no relationship to malaria susceptibility.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Duffy antigen receptor for chemokines (DARC) is essential for P. vivax and P. knowlesi malaria parasites to invade red blood cells. Individuals without this receptor are naturally resistant to these types of malaria.

questions.text: A patient's blood sample is mixed with Anit-A/B/D and the findings are shown below. What is the patient's blood type?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B+

 

Option B:

 

Agglutination with anti-B indicates the presence of B antigens on the red blood cells. Agglutination with anti-D indicates the presence of the Rh factor (positive). No agglutination with anti-A indicates the absence of A antigens.

 

Educational objective:

 

Blood typing is determined by the presence or absence of specific antigens on the surface of red blood cells.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a two-week history of easy bruising and pinprick red spots on her lower legs. She denies any recent injuries or medication use. On examination, she has multiple petechiae on her skin and mucous membranes. Blood investigations except low platelet count, imagings turned out to be normal. What's the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP)

 

Option B:

 

ITP is an autoimmune disorder characterized by isolated thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) with no other obvious cause. It is a common cause of thrombocytopenia in adults.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia: While it can cause thrombocytopenia, it also affects other cell lines (red blood cells and white blood cells).

 

Option C. Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS): MDS can cause thrombocytopenia, but it is more common in older adults and often presents with other cytopenias.

 

Option D. Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA): TMA causes thrombocytopenia through a different mechanism (platelet consumption in microvascular thrombi).

 

Educational objective:

 

ITP is a diagnosis of exclusion, meaning other causes of thrombocytopenia need to be ruled out.

choices.text: Repeat the CBC in a sodium citrate tube
Order a bone marrow biopsy
Begin heparin therapy for HIT

questions.text: A 45-year-old asymptomatic woman has a routine complete blood count (CBC) which shows a platelet count of 80,000/µL. Peripheral blood smear shows large platelet clumps. Given the likely diagnosis, Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat the CBC in a sodium citrate tube

 

Option A:

 

Repeating the CBC in a sodium citrate tube is the most appropriate next step to confirm pseudothrombocytopenia. Citrate prevents platelet clumping and will show a normal platelet count if pseudothrombocytopenia is the cause.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Start corticosteroids for ITP: Corticosteroids are used to treat ITP, but this is not appropriate until pseudothrombocytopenia is ruled out.

 

Option C. Order a bone marrow biopsy: A bone marrow biopsy is not necessary for the diagnosis of pseudothrombocytopenia.

 

Option D. Begin heparin therapy for HIT: Heparin therapy is contraindicated in HIT and should not be started until this diagnosis is ruled out.

 

Educational objective:

 

Repeating the CBC in a citrate tube is a simple and effective way to confirm pseudothrombocytopenia.

choices.text: Secondary ITP associated with CLL

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a recent diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) presents with fatigue, easy bruising, and petechiae. His platelet count is 20,000/µL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secondary ITP associated with CLL

 

Option D:

 

The patient's recent diagnosis of CLL and the absence of any other obvious cause for thrombocytopenia point towards secondary ITP. CLL is a known cause of secondary ITP.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Primary immune thrombocytopenia (ITP): While ITP presents with isolated thrombocytopenia, the presence of CLL suggests a secondary cause in this case.

 

Option B. Drug-induced thrombocytopenia: There is no mention of recent medication use to suggest this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT): HIT is an immune-mediated reaction to heparin, which is not mentioned in the patient's history.

 

Educational objective:

 

Secondary ITP can be caused by various underlying conditions, including lymphoproliferative disorders like CLL.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a 5-year history of chronic ITP has persistent thrombocytopenia (25,000/µL) despite prior treatments with corticosteroids, IVIg, and TPO-RAs. She experiences frequent bleeding and seeks further management options. Which of the following is the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Splenectomy

 

Option B:

 

Splenectomy is considered the most effective second-line therapy for chronic ITP refractory to initial treatments. It offers the highest chance of long-term remission (up to 65%), as the spleen is the primary site of platelet destruction in ITP. However, it is a surgical procedure with associated risks, including infection and thrombosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rituximab infusion: While rituximab can be effective in some patients, its response rate is lower than splenectomy and the onset of action is delayed. It also carries potential for serious side effects like infections and infusion reactions.

 

Option C. Danazol therapy: Danazol is an older medication with limited evidence of efficacy in ITP and potential for masculinizing side effects in women, making it a less preferred option.

 

Option D. Fostamatinib therapy: This is a newer option with promising results, but it has less long-term data than splenectomy and may have adverse effects like hypertension, diarrhea, and hepatotoxicity.

 

Educational objective:

 

In patients with chronic ITP refractory to initial therapies, splenectomy offers the highest chance of long-term remission, but it should be considered after weighing the risks and benefits of surgery. Other options like rituximab and fostamatinib may be considered in select cases, while danazol is less commonly used due to its limited efficacy and side effect profile.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman develops new-onset thrombocytopenia and thrombosis 6 days after initiating unfractionated heparin (UFH) for DVT prophylaxis following knee replacement surgery. Her medical history is significant for hypertension and osteoarthritis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type II Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT)

 

Option C:

 

This is the most likely diagnosis given the temporal relationship between heparin initiation and the development of thrombocytopenia and thrombosis. Type II HIT is an immune-mediated reaction that typically occurs 5-14 days after heparin exposure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP): ITP is an autoimmune disorder that can cause thrombocytopenia but is not typically associated with thrombosis.

 

Option B. Type I Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT): This is a non-immune mediated form of HIT that usually occurs within the first 2 days of heparin exposure and is not associated with thrombosis.

 

Option D. Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP): TTP is a rare disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and neurologic symptoms. It is not typically associated with heparin use.

 

Educational objective:

 

New-onset thrombocytopenia and thrombosis in a patient recently started on heparin should raise suspicion for Type II HIT, which warrants immediate discontinuation of heparin and initiation of alternative anticoagulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical clinical feature of Thrombotic Microangiopathy (TMA)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolonged PT and PTT

 

Option C:

 

PT and PTT are usually normal in TMA, as it primarily affects platelet function and does not involve the coagulation cascade.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Thrombocytopenia: A key feature of TMA due to platelet consumption in microthrombi.

 

Option B. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA): Also a key feature of TMA due to mechanical damage to red blood cells.

 

Option D. Renal dysfunction: Can occur due to microthrombi formation in the kidneys.

 

Educational objective:

 

Normal PT and PTT help differentiate TMA from other conditions like DIC, which typically present with abnormal coagulation tests.

questions.text: A patient with a history of malignant hypertension presents with MAHA, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TMA

 

Option D:

 

Malignant hypertension can cause TMA due to severe endothelial damage. The patient's history supports this diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. TTP (Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura): While TTP can present with MAHA, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury, it is typically associated with a deficiency of the ADAMTS13 enzyme. This patient's history of malignant hypertension makes TMA a more likely diagnosis.

 

Option B. HUS (Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome): HUS is often associated with Shiga-toxin producing E. coli infection and commonly presents with bloody diarrhea. The patient's history does not suggest this.

 

Option C. DIC (Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation): DIC is a consumptive coagulopathy triggered by a systemic illness (e.g., sepsis, malignancy). While it can cause MAHA and thrombocytopenia, it would typically present with abnormal coagulation parameters (prolonged PT/PTT, low fibrinogen) which are not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Educational objective:

 

It's important to consider secondary causes of TMA, such as malignant hypertension, in patients with relevant risk factors.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic mutations is NOT typically associated with familial atypical HUS?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) STXBP5

 

Option D:

 

While STXBP5 mutations can cause aHUS, they are not typically associated with the familial form of the disease. This gene is more commonly involved in a rare neurological disorder called STXBP5-related epileptic encephalopathy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CFH, Option B. CFI and Option C. CD46: These genes all encode complement regulatory proteins, and mutations in them can lead to familial aHUS.

 

Educational objective:

 

Familial atypical HUS is a genetically heterogeneous disorder with mutations in several complement regulatory genes. Recognizing the role of these genes is essential for accurate diagnosis, genetic counseling, and potential targeted therapies. While STXBP5 mutations are more commonly associated with a neurological disorder and are not typically seen in familial cases.

choices.text: Methylmalonic acidemia due to MMACHC mutation

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with lethargy, hypotonia, and developmental delay. Laboratory investigations reveal megaloblastic anemia, elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels. Which of the following conditions is MOST LIKELY to predispose this infant to thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methylmalonic acidemia due to MMACHC mutation

 

Option A:

 

Methylmalonic acidemia (MMA) due to MMACHC mutation can lead to elevated homocysteine levels, which is a known risk factor for developing thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA). TMA is a serious condition characterized by microvascular thrombosis, resulting in organ damage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) deficiency: DHFR deficiency primarily affects folate metabolism and does not directly predispose to TMA.

 

Option C. Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD): MSUD is an amino acid disorder and is not associated with increased risk of TMA.

 

Option D. Tyrosinemia type I: Tyrosinemia type I is a metabolic disorder affecting tyrosine metabolism and does not typically predispose to TMA.

 

Educational objective:

 

MMACHC mutations can lead to elevated homocysteine levels, which increases the risk of developing thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) in affected individuals.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a history of heavy menstrual bleeding since menarche. She also reports easy bruising and prolonged bleeding after minor cuts. Physical examination reveals scattered petechiae. Which of the following tests is most likely to be diagnostic?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Platelet aggregation studies

 

Option B:

 

Platelet aggregation studies are the most specific test for diagnosing Glanzmann thrombasthenia, a likely diagnosis based on the patient's history and physical examination. They will show absent or markedly reduced aggregation in response to multiple agonists.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ristocetin cofactor activity: This test measures the function of von Willebrand factor (vWF) and is used in the diagnosis of von Willebrand disease.

 

Option C. Factor VIII assay: This test is used to diagnose hemophilia A.

 

Option D. Bone marrow biopsy: This test is not indicated in the initial workup of suspected Glanzmann thrombasthenia.

 

Educational objective:

 

Platelet aggregation studies are the definitive test for diagnosing Glanzmann thrombasthenia.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with recurrent pyogenic skin and respiratory infections, silver-grey hair, and nystagmus. Peripheral blood smear reveals giant granules in neutrophils. Given the likely diagnosis, Which of the following infections is MOST frequently associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

 

Option A:

 

Patients with Chediak-Higashi syndrome are particularly susceptible to Staphylococcus aureus infections due to impaired neutrophil function.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Streptococcus pneumoniae: While patients with Chediak-Higashi syndrome may be more susceptible to infections in general, there isn't a specific predisposition towards Streptococcus pneumoniae compared to Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Pseudomonas is more commonly associated with patients with cystic fibrosis or other immunocompromised states. It's not a hallmark infection for Chediak-Higashi.

 

Option D. Candida albicans: This is a fungal infection, and while Chediak-Higashi syndrome patients may be more susceptible to infections overall, bacterial infections (especially those caused by Staphylococcus aureus) are of greater concern.

 

Educational objective:

 

Recurrent Staphylococcus aureus infections are a hallmark of Chediak-Higashi syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of easy bruising and prolonged bleeding after minor procedures undergoes laboratory testing. The results reveal a normal von Willebrand factor (vWF) antigen level, but a decreased vWF ristocetin cofactor activity (RCoF). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Von Willebrand disease (VWD) type 2

 

Option B:

 

This type of VWD is characterized by qualitative defects in vWF. While the quantity of vWF (antigen level) may be normal, its function (RCoF) is impaired, leading to bleeding problems.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Von Willebrand disease (VWD) type 1: In VWD type 1, both vWF antigen and RCoF levels are decreased proportionally, not just the RCoF.

 

Option C. Von Willebrand disease (VWD) type 3: This is the most severe form of VWD with a near-complete absence of vWF, so both antigen and RCoF would be very low.

 

Option D. Acquired von Willebrand syndrome: While this can mimic VWD, it is usually associated with underlying conditions like lymphoproliferative disorders, autoimmune diseases, or certain medications.

 

Educational objective:

 

A normal vWF antigen level with a decreased RCoF strongly suggests a qualitative defect in vWF, which is characteristic of VWD type 2. Further testing can determine the specific subtype (2A, 2B, 2M, or 2N).

choices.text: Both Factor VIII and von Willebrand Factor (vWF)
Factor VIII, vWF, and Factor IX

questions.text: Which of the following coagulation factors are increased by the administration of DDAVP?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both Factor VIII and von Willebrand Factor (vWF)

 

Option C:

 

Desmopressin (DDAVP) acts by stimulating the release of both Factor VIII and von Willebrand factor (vWF) from storage sites within endothelial cells. This leads to a temporary increase in their levels in the blood, aiding in clot formation and controlling bleeding.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Factor VIII only: While DDAVP does increase Factor VIII, it also increases vWF.

 

Option B. Factor IX only: DDAVP does not affect Factor IX levels.

 

Option D. Factor VIII, vWF, and Factor IX: This is incorrect because, as mentioned above, DDAVP does not affect Factor IX levels.

 

Educational objective:

 

DDAVP is a useful therapeutic agent in certain bleeding disorders, particularly mild hemophilia A and some types of von Willebrand disease (VWD), due to its ability to increase the levels of both Factor VIII and vWF. Understanding its mechanism of action is crucial for selecting appropriate patients for treatment and anticipating its effects.

choices.text: Evasive behavior when asked about the hematomas
History of spontaneous hematomas in paternal grandmother

questions.text: A 22-year-old man with a history of frequent nosebleeds and prolonged bleeding after a tooth extraction presents with recurrent, painless bloody urine. Examination reveals multiple hematomas and decreased range of motion with crepitus in both ankles. Laboratory studies show a normal platelet count, prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT), and hematuria without RBC casts. An x-ray of the pelvis shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intraarticular iron deposition

 

Option D:

 

Repeated hemarthrosis (bleeding into joints) is a hallmark of hemophilia. This leads to iron deposition within the joint (hemosiderin) due to the breakdown of red blood cells. Over time, this iron can cause synovitis and cartilage damage, resulting in chronic joint problems and a decreased range of motion, as seen in this patient. An MRI or ultrasound would be the best way to confirm this finding.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Evasive behavior when asked about the hematomas: While this might be present in some cases, it's not specific to hemophilia and doesn't help confirm the diagnosis.

 

Option B. History of spontaneous hematomas in paternal grandmother: While hemophilia is often inherited, a family history alone is not enough to diagnose the condition. Direct testing for factor deficiencies is needed.

 

Option C. Petechiae in the oropharynx: Petechiae are typically associated with thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), not hemophilia. This patient's platelet count is normal.

 

Educational objective:

 

In a patient with suspected hemophilia, further evaluation with imaging studies like MRI or ultrasound is essential to assess joint damage and confirm the diagnosis of hemophilic arthropathy. A positive family history can raise suspicion, but definitive diagnosis requires factor assays.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a history of mild bleeding tendencies since childhood, primarily after trauma or surgery. He is found to have prolonged PT and aPTT, both of which correct with mixing studies. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LMAN1 gene mutation

 

The patient's presentation and laboratory findings are consistent with combined factor V and factor VIII deficiency, a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the LMAN1 gene.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Factor VIII gene mutation: Causes hemophilia A, with isolated prolongation of aPTT.

 

Option B. Factor V gene mutation: Causes factor V deficiency, with isolated prolongation of PT.

 

Option D. Prothrombin gene mutation: Causes prothrombin deficiency, with isolated prolongation of PT.

 

Educational objective:

 

Combined factor V and factor VIII deficiency is associated with mutations in the LMAN1 gene, leading to mild bleeding tendencies.

choices.text: ACD (Acid citrate dextrose)

questions.text: Which blood additive provides the longest shelf life for stored red blood cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SAGM (Saline adenine glucose mannitol)

 

Option D:

 

The table shows that SAGM has a shelf life of 42 days, which is the longest among the listed additives. This is due to the presence of adenine and mannitol, which help to maintain red blood cell viability during storage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. ACD (Acid citrate dextrose): This was one of the earliest preservatives and has a relatively short shelf life (21 days). The citrate acts as an anticoagulant, while dextrose provides energy for the red blood cells.

 

Option B. CPD (Citrate phosphate dextrose): This is an improvement over ACD due to the addition of phosphate, which acts as a buffer to maintain pH. However, it still has a relatively short shelf life (21 days).

 

Option C. CP2D (Citrate phosphate double dextrose): This has double the amount of dextrose compared to CPD, providing more energy for the red blood cells and extending the shelf life slightly (28 days).

 

Educational objective:

 

SAGM is the additive that provides the longest shelf life for stored red blood cells.

questions.text: What is the main advantage of single-donor platelets (SDPs) over random-donor platelets (RDPs)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduced risk of alloimmunization

 

Option B:

 

SDPs are derived from a single donor, reducing the number of donor exposures and, therefore, the risk of alloimmunization (development of antibodies against foreign platelet antigens).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lower cost: SDPs are typically more expensive to produce than RDPs because they require apheresis, a specialized blood collection procedure.

 

Option C. Higher platelet increment: While some studies have shown slightly higher platelet increments with SDPs, the difference is not always clinically significant, and the overall efficacy in preventing bleeding is similar between SDPs and RDPs.

 

Option D. Longer shelf life: Both SDPs and RDPs have similar shelf lives, typically around 5 days when stored properly.

 

Educational objective:

 

SDPs are preferred to reduce the risk of alloimmunization in patients who may require multiple transfusions.

questions.text: A patient with severe liver disease presents with a prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and is scheduled for an invasive procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate blood product for correcting their coagulopathy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fresh frozen plasma (FFP)

 

Option C:

 

FFP contains all coagulation factors and is the most appropriate choice for correcting multiple factor deficiencies in liver disease. Cryoprecipitate contains fibrinogen and factor VIII, PCC contains vitamin K-dependent factors, and platelets are used for thrombocytopenia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cryoprecipitate: While cryoprecipitate is a source of fibrinogen and factor VIII, it would not address the multiple coagulation factor deficiencies commonly seen in liver disease.

 

Option B. Prothrombin Complex Concentrate (PCC): PCC contains vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X), but patients with liver disease may also have deficiencies in other factors not included in PCC.

 

Option D. Platelet concentrate: Platelets are used to treat thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), not coagulation factor deficiencies. While liver disease can cause thrombocytopenia, it is not the primary concern in this scenario where the patient has a prolonged PT.

 

Educational objective:

 

FFP is the preferred blood product for correcting coagulopathy in liver disease due to its comprehensive coagulation factor content.

questions.text: A patient with a history of severe febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR) is scheduled for surgery and requires a red blood cell (RBC) transfusion. The blood bank is unable to provide leukoreduced RBCs due to limited supply. Which of the following alternative methods could be considered to potentially reduce the risk of FNHTR in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) UVB-treated RBCs

 

Option C:

 

UVB-treated RBCs have been investigated as a potential alternative to leukoreduction in reducing the risk of FNHTR. While leukoreduction is the standard approach, UVB treatment may offer a similar benefit by inactivating white blood cells and reducing cytokine release.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Irradiation of RBCs: Irradiation is primarily used to prevent transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease (TA-GVHD) in immunocompromised patients. It does not specifically address the risk of FNHTR.

 

Option B. Washing of RBCs: Washing RBCs can remove some plasma proteins and antibodies, which may be helpful in preventing allergic reactions. However, it is not as effective as leukoreduction in preventing FNHTR, which is primarily caused by cytokines released from white blood cells.

 

Option D. Plasmapheresis of RBCs: Plasmapheresis is a procedure that separates plasma from blood cells and is not relevant to reducing the risk of FNHTR.

 

Educational objective:

 

UVB-treated RBCs may be considered as an alternative to leukoreduced RBCs in situations where leukoreduction is not feasible or unavailable. However, the efficacy of UVB treatment in preventing FNHTR is still under investigation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic kidney disease presents with fatigue and shortness of breath. His laboratory findings show a MCV 88 fL with a low reticulocyte production index (RPI < 2). Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of his anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anemia of chronic disease

 

Option D:

 

Chronic kidney disease is a classic cause of anemia of chronic disease, characterized by normocytic anemia with low RPI due to impaired erythropoietin production and iron utilization.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Folate deficiency: Macrocytic anemia with high RPI.

 

Option B. Iron deficiency anemia: Microcytic anemia with low RPI.

 

Option C. Hemolytic anemia: Normocytic/macrocytic anemia with high RPI.

 

Educational objective:

 

Normocytic anemia with low RPI in the setting of chronic disease should prompt consideration of anemia of chronic disease.

choices.text: Iron deficiency anemia (IDA)

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with fatigue and a normocytic anemia (MCV 90 fL). His iron studies show the following:

 

 

  • Serum iron: 30 mcg/dL (normal: 60-170 mcg/dL)
  • TIBC: 200 mcg/dL (normal: 240-450 mcg/dL)
  • Ferritin: 350 ng/mL (normal: 20-500 ng/mL)

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anemia of chronic disease (ACD)

 

Option A:

 

Anemia of chronic disease (ACD): This patient's presentation and lab values are consistent with ACD. The inflammatory response in rheumatoid arthritis disrupts iron metabolism, leading to low serum iron and TIBC, despite adequate iron stores (as indicated by the normal to elevated ferritin).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Iron deficiency anemia (IDA): IDA would typically present with low serum iron, high TIBC, and low ferritin.

 

Option C. Thalassemia trait: This is a genetic condition causing microcytic anemia, not normocytic.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic anemia (SA): SA is less likely in this scenario as it often presents with elevated serum iron and ferritin.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Recognizing the distinct pattern of iron studies in anemia of chronic disease (low serum iron, low TIBC, and normal to elevated ferritin) is crucial for differentiating it from iron deficiency anemia.
  • In the setting of a chronic inflammatory condition like rheumatoid arthritis, anemia of chronic disease is a common consideration.

choices.text: Normal serum iron, normal TIBC, and normal ferritin
Low serum iron, high TIBC, and low ferritin
Low serum iron, low TIBC, and high ferritin
High serum iron, normal TIBC, and high ferritin

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with heavy menstrual bleeding presents with fatigue and pallor. Her lab results show a microcytic anemia with an elevated red cell distribution width and a low reticulocyte count. Which of the following laboratory findings would MOST likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low serum iron, high TIBC, and low ferritin

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation and laboratory findings are consistent with iron deficiency anemia (IDA). In IDA, iron stores are depleted, leading to low serum iron and ferritin levels. The body attempts to compensate by increasing iron binding capacity (TIBC).

 

Educational objective:

 

The combination of microcytic anemia, elevated RDW, and low reticulocyte count with low serum iron, high TIBC, and low ferritin strongly suggests iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman of Mediterranean descent is found to have mild microcytic anemia on routine blood work. Her iron studies are normal, and hemoglobin electrophoresis reveals an elevated HbA2 level. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta-thalassemia trait

 

Option C:

 

Microcytic anemia with normal iron studies and elevated HbA2 on electrophoresis are characteristic of beta-thalassemia trait.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia (IDA): While IDA is the most common cause of microcytic anemia, it would typically present with abnormal iron studies (low serum iron, low ferritin, and high total iron-binding capacity).

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease (ACD): ACD is typically normocytic, but can occasionally be microcytic. However, it would not typically cause elevated HbA2 levels on electrophoresis.

 

 

Option D. Alpha-thalassemia trait: Alpha thalassemia is another inherited disorder that can cause microcytic anemia, but it would not typically cause elevated HbA2 levels. Instead, it may be associated with an elevated HbH level or a normal hemoglobin electrophoresis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Beta-thalassemia is a common cause of microcytic anemia in individuals of Mediterranean descent. Hemoglobin electrophoresis is essential for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent bacterial infections and is found to have low IgG levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

 

Option C:

 

The patient's presentation suggests a primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by hypogammaglobulinemia (low IgG levels). IVIG is the mainstay of treatment for such conditions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Plasmapheresis: This is used to remove harmful substances from blood and is not indicated in this case.

 

Option B. Corticosteroids: While corticosteroids have immunomodulatory effects, they are not the first-line treatment for hypogammaglobulinemia.

 

Option D. Rituximab: This is a monoclonal antibody targeting CD20-positive B cells and is not indicated for primary immunodeficiency.

 

Educational objective:

 

IVIG is a crucial therapy for patients with primary immunodeficiencies, providing passive immunity by supplementing IgG levels.

choices.text: MDS is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder.
Most patients with MDS will eventually progress to acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
The risk of transformation to AML is higher in patients with complex karyotype abnormalities.
Allogeneic stem cell transplantation is the only curative option for MDS.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Most patients with MDS will eventually progress to acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

 

Option B:

 

While MDS can transform into AML, the majority of patients do not progress to AML. The risk of transformation depends on several factors, including the subtype of MDS and the presence of cytogenetic abnormalities.

 

Educational objective:

 

Not all MDS patients progress to AML, and the prognosis varies depending on several factors.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with fatigue, weakness, and easy bruising. Peripheral blood smear shows macrocytic anemia and dysplastic neutrophils. Cytogenetic analysis reveals a deletion in the long arm of chromosome 5 (del(5q)). According to the IPSS-R, what is the patient's prognostic risk category?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low

 

Option B:

 

The presence of del(5q) is associated with a good prognosis in MDS, and the patient's age and blood count findings suggest a lower-risk disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Very Low: While del(5q) MDS is a lower-risk subtype, it doesn't fall into the "very low" category, which is usually reserved for patients with very few cytopenias and no cytogenetic abnormalities.

 

Option C. Intermediate: This category typically includes patients with more cytopenias or less favorable cytogenetic findings than those with isolated del(5q).

 

Option D. High: These categories are reserved for MDS with a high risk of progression to acute myeloid leukemia (AML), which is not typical of isolated del(5q). These patients usually have excess blasts in the bone marrow, complex karyotypes, or specific genetic mutations associated with worse outcomes.

 

Educational objective:

 

Del(5q) is a favorable cytogenetic abnormality in MDS associated with a better prognosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fatigue, weight loss, and abdominal fullness. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly. Peripheral blood smear shows a leukocytosis with left shift. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BCR-ABL1

 

Option B:

 

The clinical presentation of fatigue, weight loss, splenomegaly, and leukocytosis with left shift, strongly suggests chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). The BCR-ABL1 fusion gene is the hallmark of CML and results from a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. JAK2 V617F: Associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs) like polycythemia vera (PV), essential thrombocythemia (ET), and primary myelofibrosis (PMF).

 

Option C. FLT3-ITD: More commonly associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

 

Option D. t(15;17): Associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of AML.

 

Educational objective:

 

BCR-ABL1 fusion gene is the diagnostic hallmark of CML.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic hallmark of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) t(9;22) translocation (Philadelphia chromosome)

 

Option C:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from the t(9;22) translocation, is the characteristic genetic abnormality found in virtually all cases of CML.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. JAK2 V617F mutation: This mutation is associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs), not CML.

 

Option B. t(15;17) translocation: This translocation is the hallmark of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).

 

Option D. t(8;21) translocation: This translocation is associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

 

Educational objective:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome is the defining genetic feature of CML.

questions.text: Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is associated with a high risk of relapse in AML?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) -5/del(5q)

 

Option D:

 

Monosomy 5 or deletion of the long arm of chromosome 5 (5q-) is associated with a poor prognosis in AML and a high risk of relapse.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. inv(16): This inversion is associated with acute myeloid leukemia with abnormal eosinophils (AML M4Eo) and generally has a favorable prognosis.

 

Option B. t(15;17): This translocation is the hallmark of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of AML. APL has a good prognosis when treated promptly with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and arsenic trioxide (ATO).

 

Option C. t(8;21): This translocation is associated with acute myeloid leukemia with maturation (AML M2) and also has a relatively favorable prognosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Cytogenetic abnormalities can significantly impact prognosis and treatment choices in AML.
